title: ‘Fit and healthy’ girl, 15, collapsed and died after choking on food
text:
Abby Reese Beaumont, 15, died suddenly at home after choking on food, her inquest heard (Picture: North Wales Live)

A devastated father says his family have been ‘waiting in limbo’ to find out how his ‘beautiful’ teenager daughter collapsed and died.

Abby Reese Beaumont, 15, started coughing and collapsed on her kitchen floor on 2 April.

Her dad Darren, 51, was with her at the time but said he and Abby’s mum, Alison, and younger sister Jessica, 13, have been searching for answers over her cause of death ever since.

At her inquest this week, a pathologist said Abby had choked on food, giving a provisional cause of death as ‘foreign body aspiration caused by food stuffs’.

The family, of Mold, Wales, visited Abby’s old school to explain what happened to fellow pupils ahead of the inquest opening.

Darren thanked the school and Abby’s friends for their ‘overwhelming’ support since the tragedy.

He said: ‘For five months we’ve been hanging in limbo waiting for answers over Abby’s death.

‘We wanted to know what the cause of death was, we waited a long time and we questioned everything.

‘We thought Abby was in perfect health and she was. It is such a sad way to die and we have been through a rollercoaster of emotions and we are devastated.

‘But we want to express our gratitude to the school and the children, some of them have been so special to us it’s been incredible.’

The family thanked teachers and friends of Abby for their ‘overwhelming’ support (Picture: North Wales Live)

Darren added: ‘When Abby died, it was more like losing a friend. That’s the kind of relationship we had.

‘Abby was beautiful, outgoing and confident but nice and caring with it and she always looked out for younger children.

‘She loved languages and could speak French and Welsh fluently. She was doing remarkably well at school and had only just started talking about what she wanted to do with her future.’

Abby’s inquest in Ruthin, north Wales, was opened and adjourned ahead of a full inquest into her death due to be held next year.

Darren said: ‘The amount of people who came to us after she died proved how many people it had affected far and wide and how much she was loved by so many.’
